Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Option [B]

Attach the VPN template to the device template for the device managed by Cisco SD-WAN.
Configure Service Chaining Using Cisco vManage

To configure service chaining for a device.

1. In Cisco vManage, create a VPN template.

2. ClickService.

3. In the Service section, click New Service and configure the following:

4. Service Type: Select the type of service that the service device is providing.

5. IP Address: IP Address is the only working option.

IPv4 Address: Enter between one and four addresses for the device.

Tracking: Determines whether the periodic health updates of the service device are recorded in the system log. Default: On

Note
Maximum number of services: 8

 https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge-20-x/policies-book/service-chaining.html

questions.question_text: The Cisco SD-WAN engineer is configuring service chaining for a next-generation firewall located at the headquarters. Which configuration creates the service?

discussion.content: Always vbond first point of contact, if valid, then the device will get the informations of the other controllers to join the sdwan fabric.

Selected Answer: A
vBond is the first point of connection. It helps to share all controller info to vedge and to authenticate the vedge.
Answer is a

Selected Answer: A
A.
The SD-WAN Validator (formerly known as vBond) provides this function. See link from steed47.

Selected Answer: A
Answer A is correct.

Cisco vBond Orchestrator orchestrates the initial control connection between Cisco vSmart Controllers and edge routers. It creates DTLS tunnels to the Cisco vSmart Controllers and edge routers to authenticate each node that is requesting control plane connectivity. This authentication behavior assures that only valid customer nodes can participate 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/sdwan-xe-gs-book/system-overview.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The component of the Cisco SD-WAN network that assures only valid customer nodes are participating in the overlay network is:

C. vSmart

vSmart controllers in the Cisco SD-WAN architecture are responsible for control plane functions. They act as the brain of the SD-WAN network and are involved in determining the best path for data traffic through the overlay network. Additionally, they verify the authenticity and validity of customer nodes, ensuring that only authorized devices participate in the SD-WAN overlay network.

questions.question_text: Which component of the Cisco SD-WAN network assures that only valid customer nodes are participating in the overlay network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
vManage NMS Redundancy
A highly available Cisco SD-WAN network contains three or more vManage NMSs in each domain. This scenario is referred to as a cluster of vManage NMSs, and each vManage NMS in a cluster is referred to as a vManage instance. Each vManage instance or device in a cluster can manage approximately 2000 devices, so a cluster of three vManage devices can manage up to 6000 devices. The vManage devices automatically load-balances the devices that they manage. With three devices, the vManage cluster remains operational if one of the devices in that cluster fail.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/optimization-ha/vedge/network-optimization-high-availability-book/high-availability.html

Selected Answer: D
A highly available Cisco SD-WAN network contains three or more vManage NMSs in each domain.

questions.question_text: How many vManage NMSs should be installed in each domain to achieve scalability and redundancy?

choices.D: three or more in a cluster
choices.C: two or more in a cluster

Selected Answer: AB
A and B.
The other answers C,D,E are all random examples of policy functions, but since it says THE two components, that would be lists and policy definitions (and policy definitions include all the functions mentioned in C,D,E).

The two components of centralized policy deployment in vManage are:

A. policy definition
E. route policy

Explanation:

Policy Definition: Policy definition refers to the creation and configuration of policies that define how the network traffic should be treated, controlled, and prioritized. These policies can include various aspects, such as application-aware firewall policies, Quality of Service (QoS) policies, VPN policies, security policies, and more.

Route Policy: Route policies are used to control the advertisement and acceptance of routes between different routing domains within the SD-WAN network. They help in controlling the flow of traffic and implementing traffic engineering decisions based on network conditions, link performance, and other criteria.

The other options (B. lists, C. QoS map, and D. policy-based routing) are not components of centralized policy deployment in vManage. While they may be relevant in other contexts or for specific configurations, they are not the primary components involved in deploying policies centrally within the Cisco SD-WAN solution.

questions.question_text: What are the two components of centralized policy deployment in vManage? (Choose two.)
